children.name: when one statement, idea etc makes a different one seem untrue
contradict
children.definition: /ˌkɒntrəˈdɪktǁˌkɑːn-/  if one statement or fact contradicts another one, it is so different that it makes the other one seem untrue or impossible:
examples: contradictory/ˌkɒntrəˈdɪktəri◂ǁˌkɑːn-/ [adjective] ideas, statements, results etc that are contradictory are different from each other, especially when you would expect them to be the same:
mâu thuẫn
▪ The two boys gave contradictory accounts of the accident.
Hai cậu bé đưa ra những lời khai mâu thuẫn về vụ tai nạn.
▪ A lot of the information we receive from historical sources is contradictory, inaccurate, or incomplete.
Nhiều thông tin thu thập được từ các tài liệu lịch sử khá mâu thuẫn, sai lệch hoặc không đầy đủ.

children.name: mâu thuẫn, trái ngược
examples: ▪ The two newspaper reports totally contradict each other.
Hai tờ báo đưa thông tin hoàn toàn trái ngược nhau.
▪ Recent experiments seem to contradict earlier results.
Những thí nghiệm gần đây dường như trái ngược hoàn toàn với các kết quả trước.
▪ O'Brien’s later statement contradicted what he had told Somerville police on the night of the murder.

children.name: Tuyên bố sau này của O'Brien trái với những gì ông đã nói với cảnh sát Somerville về đêm xảy ra án mạng
conflicting
children.definition: /kənˈflɪktɪŋ/  very different from each other - use this especially when two things should be the same:

children.name: đối lập, mâu thuẫn
examples: ▪ At first we received conflicting information about the number of children who were seriously hurt.
Lúc đầu chúng tôi nhận được những thông tin khác nhau về số trẻ em bị thương nặng.
▪ Researchers tend to offer conflicting advice on which vitamin and mineral supplements might keep us healthy.
Các nhà nghiên cứu thường đưa ra những lời khuyên khác nhau về các vitamin và chất khoáng bổ sung giúp bảo vệ sức khỏe.

children.name: be inconsistent with
children.definition: /biː ˌɪnkənˈsɪstənt wɪð/  if a statement, story, fact etc is inconsistent with what you expect or already know of the situation, it is completely different from it:

children.name: không đúng với
examples: ▪ IBM said that the £37 million payment had been made in a way that was inconsistent with company policy.
IBM nói rằng khoản tiền 37 triệu đô đã không được xử lý đúng theo chính sách công ty.
▪ Wolff, an economics professor at New York University, said that the results were inconsistent with all the other data they had.
Wolff, chuyên gia kinh tế ở Đại học New York, nói rằng kết quả không khớp với dữ liệu họ thu thập được.

children.name: discrepancy
children.definition: a small fact or detail that is different from what you expected, especially one that makes you think that sth is wrong:sự khác nhau, không nhất quán
examples: ▪ Whenever he works out his accounts there are always discrepancies.

children.name: discrepancy between
examples: ▪ Apparently there were discrepancies between police reports taken from the same witnesses at different times.

children.name: discrepancy in
examples: ▪ She always refused to discuss the discrepancies in her biography.

children.name: go against
children.definition: /ˌgəʊ əˈgenst/  if something goes against what you think or what someone has told you, it is different from the opinions, attitudes etc that you have learnt:

children.name: đi ngược lại, khác với
examples: ▪ What the teacher was saying went against everything his parents had taught him.
▪ She couldn’t explain what had made her go against her upbringing and character and behave so recklessly.

children.name: be at odds with
children.definition: /biː ət ˈɒdz wɪð ǁ-ˈɑːdz-/  if a statement, story, fact etc is at odds with another, the two things are so completely different that one of them must be untrue:

children.name: bất đồng, không giống
examples: ▪ John Nelson has been re-examining the evidence, and his conclusions are greatly at odds with the story so far.
John Nelson đã kiểm tra lại các bằng chứng, và kết luận của anh ta thật khác với những gì được kể.
▪ The government decision to raise taxes was at odds with their policies on inflation.
Quyết định tăng thuế của chính phủ đi ngược với các chính sách lạm phát.

children.name: when sth is of the same type, but not the same one
another
children.definition: /əˈnʌðəʳ/  one more of the same kind of thing or person:
examples: cái khác
▪ Louise has a house in New York, and another in Florida.
Louise có một căn nhà ở Neww York, và một cái khác ở Florida.
▪ The blue suitcase is broken. Have we got another I could use?
Cái cặp xanh bị hỏng. Chúng ta có cái nào khác không?
▪ creatures from another planet
sinh vật từ hành tinh khác
another one
cái khác
▪ I decided I didn’t like the dress after all, so I changed it for another one.
Tôi quyết định không thích chiếc váy, nên sau cùng đã đổi cái khác.

children.name: other
children.definition: /ˈʌðəʳ/  different ones from the ones that you already have, or that you have already mentioned:

children.name: (cái) khác
examples: ▪ I’m afraid we don’t have these jeans in any other sizes.
Tôi e là chúng tôi không còn kích cỡ khác cho cái quần này.
▪ Of course, my train was late, but the others seemed to be on time.
Đương nhiên là chuyến tàu của tôi đã trễ, nhưng chuyến khác có vẻ đúng giờ.
▪ Maria’s blond, but all my other children have dark hair.
Maria tóc vàng, nhưng những đứa khác thì tóc đen.

children.name: different
children.definition: /ˈdɪfərənt/  use this about several people or things of the same general type, when you are comparing them with each other and noticing the differences between them:

children.name: khác
examples: ▪ Let’s compare the prices of five different detergents.

children.name: ▪ a drug that affects different people in different ways
new
children.definition: /njuːǁnuː/  use this about something or someone that replaces the one that was there before:mới
examples: ▪ Have you met Keith’s new girlfriend?
▪ She’s really enjoying her new job.

children.name: else
children.definition: /els/  use this after a noun to talk about another thing, place, or person instead of this one:

children.name: cái khác
examples: ▪ Go and play somewhere else. I’m trying to work.
Đi chỗ khác chơi đi. Bố đang làm việc.
▪ Andrea’s obsessed with money -- she never thinks about anything else.
Andrea bị ám ảnh về tiền- cô ta không bao giờ nghĩ về cái gì khác.
▪ Jamie’s special. There’s really no one else like him.
Jamie rất đặc biệt. Thật sự không có ai được như anh ta.

children.name: alternative
children.definition: alsoalternateUS  an alternative plan, arrangement, or system can be used instead of the usual or main one:thay thế, khác
examples: ▪ For vegetarian guests there is an alternative menu.
▪ The bridge is closed so we advise you to use an alternate route.
▪ Do you have any alternative suggestions to make?

children.name: variation
children.definition: sth that is done in a way that is different from the way it is usually done:sự biến đổi, sự thay đổi, dao động

children.name: variation on
examples: ▪ This recipe makes an interesting variation on the traditional Christmas cake.

children.name: a variation on the theme of sth
examples: ▪ The new movie is a variation on the theme of the original ‘Blue Lagoon’.

children.name: variation in
examples: ▪ There are at least ten styles of Apple Mac computers, and countless variations in those models.

children.name: variant
children.definition: sth that is slightly different from the usual form of something or has developed from it:biến thể
examples: ▪ The English and Americans often spell words differently, but both variants are acceptable.
▪ The name Lloyd and its variant Floyd are Celtic in origin.

children.name: variant of
examples: ▪ There is evidence that a new variant of the disease has recently been found in Britain.

children.name: differently
children.definition: theo cách khác
examples: ▪ The words ‘through' and ’threw' sound the same, but they are spelled differently.

children.name: differently from
examples: ▪ I always felt that my parents treated me differently from my brothers and sisters.

children.name: see/look at sth differentlyhave a different opinion
examples: ▪ I believe you, but I think the police might see it differently.

children.name: along different lines U
children.definition: along different lines using a different method or system:hệ thống/ phương pháp khác
examples: ▪ Their organization was run along different lines to ours.

children.name: otherwise
children.definition: if you do, say, or think otherwise, you do, say, or think something different from what has already been mentioned:
examples: ▪ The situation was very serious indeed, even if the government tried to pretend otherwise.
▪ The police stressed that Straskow would be considered innocent until proved otherwise.

children.name: in a different way
children.definition: ▪ These three chemicals react to heat in slightly different ways.
examples: ▪ He started to treat me in a different way once we got married.

children.name: in a different way from
examples: ▪ I always felt that my parents treated me in a different way from my brothers and sisters.

children.name: different
children.definition: if sb/sth is different, they are not like sb/sth else, or they are not like they were before:
examples: ▪ You look different. Have you had your hair cut?
▪ People are all so different. You can never tell how they will react.
▪ Things are different now, since John left.
▪ We’ve painted the door a different colour.
differently[adv] B1
The two words sound the same, but they’re spelled differently.

children.name: different fromalsodifferent thanUS
examples: ▪ This computer’s different from the one I used in my last job.
▪ Life today is different than ten, fifteen years ago.

children.name: completely/ totally different
examples: ▪ I’d like a totally different look in the kitchen - something brighter and more modern.

children.name: not like
children.definition: different from - use this especially whentwothings or people are notat allsimilar:không giống
examples: ▪ Walking in the hills isn’t like walking down the street - it can be very dangerous.

children.name: not at all like/nothing likecompletely different from
examples: ▪ She’s very shy - not at all like her sister.
▪ James was nothing like I’d expected, from what I had heard.

children.name: not look/ sound like
examples: ▪ The voice on the answering machine didn’t sound like Anna’s at all.

children.name: not the same
children.definition: different - use this especially whentwothings aresimilarbut arenotexactlylike each other, or when one of them is notas good asthe other:
examples: ▪ The two designs are similar but not the same. Which do you prefer?
▪ I prefer having my own house. Living in a rented flat really isn’t the same.

children.name: not the same as
examples: ▪ I’ve tried Mexican food here in London, but it just isn’t the same as in Mexico.

children.name: vary
children.definition: if things of thesametypevary, they are all different from each other:khác nhau
examples: ▪ Methods of treatment vary according to the age and general health of the patient.

children.name: vary considerably/ greatly/ widely
examples: ▪ Prices of video cameras vary considerably.

children.name: vary in price/ quality/ size etc
examples: ▪ The hotel rooms vary in size, but all have televisions and telephones.

children.name: differ
children.definition: formalif two things differ, they have different qualities or features:khác nhau
examples: ▪ People’s abilities differ, but their rights and opportunities should be the same.

children.name: differ from
examples: ▪ Scottish law has always differed from English law.

children.name: differ in cost/ size/ appearance etc
examples: ▪ A lot of painkillers are basically the same, differing only in cost.

children.name: differ greatly/ widely
examples: ▪ Opinions on the subject differ greatly.

children.name: contrast with
children.definition: if one thing contrasts with another thing, the difference between them is very easy to see and is sth surprising:đối lập với, tương phản với
examples: ▪ His extrovert personality contrasts with his sister’s quiet, shy character.
▪ The snow was icy and white, contrasting with the brilliant blue sky.

children.name: contrast sharply/ markedlywithsth
examples: ▪ These results contrast sharply with those of similar tests carried out in Australia.

children.name: be a departure from
children.definition: a method, way of behaving etc that is a departure from the usual one is different, new, and unusual:
examples: ▪ Such methods are, of course, a departure from traditional medical practice.

children.name: mark/ represent/ signal a departure from sth
examples: ▪ The move represented a departure from the government’s commitment to finding a peaceful solution to the crisis.

children.name: diverse
children.definition: things that are diverse are different from each other and cover a wide range of possible styles, types etc:đa dạng
examples: The music college aims to encourage talents as diverse as members of symphony orchestras and pop groups.
diverse political views
a diverse range of sth
People enter the organisation from a diverse range of social, economic, and educational backgrounds.

children.name: far removed from
children.definition: be sth formal to be very different from something
examples: It's a wonderful experience but it's far removed from reality.
The events in the newspaper article were far removed from reality.

children.name: have nothing in common
children.definition: if two or more people or things have nothing in common, they do not have thesamequalities, opinions, or interests:không có điểm gì chung
examples: ▪ Apart from the fact that we went to the same school, we have absolutely nothing in common.

children.name: have nothing in common with
examples: ▪ Batavia was a completely new modern city, having very little in common with other Indonesian towns.

children.name: bear no relation to
children.definition: to be completely different from and not connected in any way with another person or thing:không liên quan
examples: ▪ Everyone complains that the national tests bear no relation to what children have learnt in class.

children.name: ▪ I was astonished when I read the press release, which bore no relation to what I had told them
poles apart
children.definition: / worlds apart people, beliefs, or ideas that are worlds or poles apart are so completely different that there is almost nothing about them that is similar: hai thái cực đối lập, hai thế giới khác
examples: I don’t know why Max took an interest in me. We were always worlds apart.

children.name: worlds apart/ poles apart from
examples: The children were on holiday, enjoying a lifestyle worlds apart from the one they had to put up with at home.

children.name: far cry
children.definition: be a  from if a situation is a far cry from another situation or place, it is so different that it is almost the opposite:khác hẳn
examples: We had dinner at the Ritz, a far cry from our usual hamburger and fries.
The first Olympic Games in 1896 were a far cry from the slick spectacle of today.

children.name: world of difference
children.definition: there’s a  between if you say there is a world of difference between two activities or situations, you mean that they are completely different from each other and people should not expect them to be the same:có một sự khác biệt rõ rệt
examples: There is a world of difference between home-made bread and the tasteless substance that many people buy today.

children.name: whole new ball game
children.definition: be a  especially US, informal to be very different from what you have done or experienced before:là một chuyện hoàn toàn khác
examples: Being married is one thing, but having children is a whole new ball game.

children.name: chalk and cheese
children.definition: be like  UKinformalif two people who are related or good friends are like chalk and cheese, they are completely different in a way that surprises you:hoàn toàn khác nhau, “như phấn và phô mai”
examples: It’s hard to believe that they’re brothers -- they’re like chalk and cheese!

children.name: alternative
children.definition: noun
examples: something that is different from something else, especially from what is usual,
and offering the possibility of choice
_an alternativetocoffee
_There must be an alternativetopeople sleeping on the streets.
_I'm afraid I havenoalternativebut toask you to leave (= that is what I have to do) .

children.name: unlike
children.definition: prepositionDIFFERENT FROM

children.name: different from
examples: _Dan's actually quite nice, unlike his father.
_Unlike you, I'm not a great dancer.

children.name: clash
children.definition: nounFIGHT
examples: [ C usually singular ]a situation in which people's opinions or qualities are very
different from and opposed to each other
_a clash of opinions/loyalties/personalities

children.name: margin
children.definition: nounDIFFERENCE

children.name: the amount by which one thing is different from another
examples: _The Senate approved the use of military force by a margin of 52 votes to 47.
_The poll shows that the government is leading by thenarrowestof margins.

children.name: unlike
children.definition: prepositionNOT TYPICAL

children.name: not typical or characteristic of
examples: _It's unlike you to be quiet – is something wrong?
